unnormalised: Okay, so someone asked about the diff between different medical titles. It's a pretty common q, so let's break it down, especially since things get a bit confusing, right?
normalised: Okay, so someone asked about the difference between different medical titles. It is a pretty common question, so let us break it down, especially since things get a bit confusing, right?

unnormalised: First off, you’ve got the basic “Dr.” – short for Doctor. Anyone with an MBBS (Bachelor of Medicine and Bachelor of Surgery) degree in India, or an equivalent MD (Doctor of Medicine) or DO (Doctor of Osteopathic Medicine) degree from other countries can use “Dr.” before their name. Dr. Sharma might be your general physician at Apollo Clinic, or Dr. Khan could be the pediatrician down the street. It just means they’ve completed their medical degree.
normalised: First off, you have got the basic “Dr.” – short for Doctor. Anyone with an M-B-B-S (Bachelor of Medicine and Bachelor of Surgery) degree in India, or an equivalent M-D (Doctor of Medicine) or D-O (Doctor of Osteopathic Medicine) degree from other countries can use “Dr.” before their name. Doctor Sharma might be your general physician at Apollo Clinic, or Doctor Khan could be the pediatrician down the street. It just means they have completed their medical degree.

unnormalised: Now, things get a little more interesting. After the MBBS, a lot of doctors go on to specialize. They’ll do a post-graduate degree like an MD (Doctor of Medicine, but a postgraduate one!), MS (Master of Surgery), or a DNB (Diplomate of National Board). So, Dr. Gupta might have an MD in Internal Medicine, making him a specialist in diagnosing and treating diseases of the internal organs. Or, Dr. Patel could have an MS in General Surgery, meaning they’re a qualified surgeon. Dr. Iyer might hold a DNB in Cardiology.
normalised: Now, things get a little more interesting. After the M-B-B-S, a lot of doctors go on to specialize. They will do a post-graduate degree like an M-D (Doctor of Medicine, but a postgraduate one!), M-S (Master of Surgery), or a D-N-B (Diplomate of National Board). So, Doctor Gupta might have an M-D in Internal Medicine, making him a specialist in diagnosing and treating diseases of the internal organs. Or, Doctor Patel could have an M-S in General Surgery, meaning they are a qualified surgeon. Doctor Iyer might hold a D-N-B in Cardiology.

unnormalised: Then you've got super-specialists. They do further training AFTER their MD or MS. For example, someone who has an MD in Internal Medicine might then do a DM (Doctorate of Medicine – confusing, I know!) in Cardiology. Or, a surgeon with an MS in General Surgery could do an MCh (Magister Chirurgiae – Master of Surgery, but for super-specialization) in Neurosurgery. So, Dr. Verma might be a DM in Neurology, specializing in the brain and nervous system. Dr. Singh might be an MCh in Plastic Surgery.
normalised: Then you have got super-specialists. They do further training after their M-D or M-S. For example, someone who has an M-D in Internal Medicine might then do a D-M (Doctorate of Medicine – confusing, I know!) in Cardiology. Or, a surgeon with an M-S in General Surgery could do an M-Ch (Magister Chirurgiae – Master of Surgery, but for super-specialization) in Neurosurgery. So, Doctor Verma might be a D-M in Neurology, specializing in the brain and nervous system. Doctor Singh might be an M-Ch in Plastic Surgery.

unnormalised: Also, keep an eye out for titles like "Prof." This usually means they're a professor at a medical college and are involved in teaching as well as practicing medicine. Prof. Banerjee, for example, might be the Head of the Department of Cardiology at AIIMS Delhi. They often have a wealth of experience and are leaders in their field.
normalised: Also, keep an eye out for titles like “Prof.” This usually means they are a professor at a medical college and are involved in teaching as well as practicing medicine. Professor Banerjee, for example, might be the Head of the Department of Cardiology at A-I-I-M-S Delhi. They often have a wealth of experience and are leaders in their field.

unnormalised: "Registrar" and "Resident" are training positions. A Resident is typically someone in their initial years of post-graduate training, whereas a Registrar is a bit more senior. They're both working under the supervision of senior doctors and specialists, gaining experience and further honing their skills. You might see Dr. Reddy as a Registrar in the Neurology dept or Dr. Kumar as a Resident in Internal Med.

You might see Doctor Reddy as a Registrar in the Neurology department or Doctor Kumar as a Resident in Internal Med.

unnormalised: Finally, there are alternative medicine practitioners who might also use "Dr." if they have a recognized degree in their field, like a BAMS (Bachelor of Ayurvedic Medicine and Surgery) or BHMS (Bachelor of Homeopathic Medicine and Surgery). So, Dr. Trivedi might be an Ayurvedic doctor prescribing herbal remedies. It's important to know the type of medicine they practice. Just remember, while they use the "Dr." title, their training and treatments are very different from those of allopathic (modern medicine) doctors. So it is important to know if Dr. Kapoor is an MD or a BHMS graduate.
